Lab-Grown Meat Statistical Analysis

Data Descriptions

Full Text Data

  • Count of articles per country
  • Count of articles over time overall
  • Articles over time per country (six lines in a chart)

Sentences Around Keywords

  • Count of sentences per country
  • Count of sentences over time overall
  • Count of sentences per country over time

Impact of Regulation on Media

Full Text Data (only USA for now)

Sentences Around Keywords

T-test (Sentiment)

This analysis applies the t-test to assess whether regulatory events significantly affect media sentiment towards lab-grown meat, typically using sentiment scores from U.S. articles and comparing pre-event and post-event sentiment.

  • Data_collection_Regulatory Data_MERGED_cleaned.xlsx
  • dataframe_usa_sliced.pickle

ANOVA

This analysis uses one-way ANOVA to evaluate whether regulatory events significantly impact sentiment scores related to lab-grown meat. ANOVA is typically used to test for significant differences between the means of three or more groups. In this context, we analyze sentiment scores of articles published before, during, and after regulatory events within 1-month, 2-month, and 3-month windows.

  • Data_collection_Regulatory Data_MERGED_cleaned.xlsx
  • dataframe_usa_sliced.pickle

MANOVA

This analysis uses the MANOVA test to evaluate whether regulatory events significantly impact sentiment and emotion scores of articles related to lab-grown meat. The MANOVA test is typically applied to test the difference in means of multiple dependent variables across groups. In this context, we analyze sentiment and emotion scores before and after regulatory events within 1-month, 2-month, and 3-month windows.

  • Data_collection_Regulatory Data_MERGED_cleaned.xlsx
  • dataframe_usa_sliced.pickle

Impact of Media on Regulation

Full Text Data (only USA for now)

Sentences Around Keywords

Cross Correlation

This analysis does a cross-correlation to examine the relationship between media sentiment and regulatory events. It is usually implied to test the influence or lead-lag relationship between two time series. We apply it on the following data: daily media sentiment scores and daily regulatory events from the USA.

  • Data_collection_Regulatory Data_MERGED_cleaned.xlsx
  • dataframe_usa_sliced.pickle

Logistic Regression

This analysis aims to determine the relationship between high media attention and the occurrence of events. Logistic regression is applied to test this hypothesis using a dataset comprising sentiment scores and regulatory events data.

  • Data_collection_Regulatory Data_MERGED_cleaned.xlsx
  • dataframe_usa_sliced.pickle

Cox Model

This analysis does survival analysis to test the timing of regulatory events and their relation to various factors. Two different models were evaluated:

  • Model 1: Variables include Event Type and Support Type
  • Model 2: Variables include Event Type, Support Type, average sentiment, average emotion, and average hype
